citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility was found to not be following appropriate methods to prevent and treat injuries for the two wallabies. On
Saturday, September 28, 2024, the facility observed a male wallaby named Chubs with torn claws on the back left middle
toe and right front 4th digit toe. A male wallaby named Cisco had a torn claw on the right rear outside toe. The facility
attempted to contact the attending veterinarian on the September 28, 2024, but did not receive a response. The facility
has been treating the injured toes with saline and silver sulfadiazine cream. Upon examination, the torn areas appear to
be tender, with the wallabies withdrawing their paws when examination is attempted. The remaining nailbeds are
extremely short and beginning to scab over. Many overgrown claws on other toes are curved and shift to the side when
weight is applied.
Appropriate and timely veterinary care is required to provide assessment and treatment, and to prevent additional
unnecessary pain and distress in animals. The licensee must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and
treat diseases and injuries. This includes the availability to provide emergency, weekend, and holiday veterinary care.
Appropriate veterinary care in this situation also includes methods to ensure the nails are kept at the proper length to
prevent future injuries. The attending veterinarian must evaluate the wallabies and determine an appropriate plan for
diagnosis and treatment.
Correct by October 2, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility was found to not be following appropriate methods to prevent and treat injuries for the two wallabies. On 
Saturday, September 28, 2024, the facility observed a male wallaby named Chubs with torn claws on the back left middle 
toe and right front 4th digit toe. A male wallaby named Cisco had a torn claw on the right rear outside toe. The facility 
attempted to contact the attending veterinarian on the September 28, 2024, but did not receive a response. The facility 
has been treating the injured toes with saline and silver sulfadiazine cream. Upon examination, the torn areas appear to 
be tender, with the wallabies withdrawing their paws when examination is attempted. The remaining nailbeds are 
extremely short and beginning to scab over. Many overgrown claws on other toes are curved and shift to the side when 
weight is applied.  
 
Appropriate and timely veterinary care is required to provide assessment and treatment, and to prevent additional 
unnecessary pain and distress in animals. The licensee must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and 
treat diseases and injuries. This includes the availability to provide emergency, weekend, and holiday veterinary care. 
Appropriate veterinary care in this situation also includes methods to ensure the nails are kept at the proper length to 
prevent future injuries. The attending veterinarian must evaluate the wallabies and determine an appropriate plan for 
diagnosis and treatment. 
 
Correct by October 2, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
